ENTRY.SYNOPSIS: Create a trace plot of iteration number vs. sampled value.

DESC.PARA: The plot_trace() function creates trace plot of the input array of data values (a NumPy ndarray), with iteration number along the x-axis and sampled value along the y-axis. The x-axis is labeled "iteration", and the y-axis and plot title are named "x" by default (may be changed with 'name' argument).

ROW.DATA: NumPy ndarray of histogram data values
label to assign to the y-axis of sampled values, and title to assign to the plot
Should previously-calculated arrays be used to create the plot?
If True, then add the data to the current plot, otherwise erase the frame and create a new plot.
If True, then do not delete any existing frames in the current ChIPS window. Note that the plots will be created in a new ChIPS frame even when this argument is set.

DESC.PARA: Create the trace plot for a simulated energy flux distribution returned by the sample_energy_flux() command (see 'ahelp sample_energy_flux'), using a custom y-axis label (also sets plot title).
DESC.VERBATIM: sherpa> a = sample_energy_flux(0.5,7.,num=1000) sherpa> plot_energy_flux() sherpa> x = a[:,0] sherpa> plot_trace(x, name="Energy Flux")

DESC.PARA: Define a histogram in the variable "x" and create the corresponding trace plot of iteration number versus sampled value, with default settings.
DESC.VERBATIM: sherpa> import numpy as np sherpa> mu, sigma = 100, 15 sherpa> x = mu + sigma*np.random.randn(10000) sherpa> plot_trace(x)
